title: How to Make Fermented Plant Juice (Organic Fertilizer)

steps.headline: Combine the raw materials (see Things You'll Need below) in a 1:1:1 ratio.
steps.description: Example: 1 kg. plant materials, 1 kg. brown sugar, 1 gallon (3.8 L) water. This can be reduced, just remember the ratio.

steps.headline: Place the materials in a large water-proof container.
steps.description: Mix the materials together until the sugar is dissolved in water.

steps.headline: Cover the container with a piece of cloth and secure with a rubber band.
Place the container in a quiet, cool and shaded location (such as a garage).
steps.description: Make sure the container won't be disturbed.

steps.headline: Leave the container for about a week.
steps.description:
Do not disturb or move it as much as possible.A week later, you will notice molds growing on the surface. The liquid will have a sweet-sour smell. It may be disturbing but its worth it. It is a sign that beneficial bacteria has inhabited the liquid. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8a\/Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8a\/Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Mix the liquid thoroughly with a stick.
Strain the liquid into a large plastic bottle, using a strainer.
steps.description: Leave enough space for the bacteria to breath. The solid materials can be placed into the compost pile, if you have. Otherwise, throw it in the trash.

steps.headline: Put the bottle cap loosely on to allow air to enter.
Place the bottle in a dark, protected area such as a garage.
Application: Mix 1 cup of the liquid to 1 gallon (3.8 L) of chemical-free water.
steps.description: It is best applied early in the morning or late afternoon. Use the diluted liquid to water the plants at their bases. For most plants, apply the diluted FPJ at least once a week.

tyn: Plant parts of fast growing plants (legumes have plenty of Nitrogen)
A large plastic container, large enough to contain 1 gallon (3.8 L) water(e.g. bucket)
Plastic Bottles w/ cap (1L soda bottles, gallon bottles, etc.)
text:
Combine the raw materials (see Things You'll Need below) in a 1:1:1 ratio. Example: 1 kg. plant materials, 1 kg. brown sugar, 1 gallon (3.8 L) water. This can be reduced, just remember the ratio. Place the materials in a large water-proof container. Mix the materials together until the sugar is dissolved in water. Cover the container with a piece of cloth and secure with a rubber band. Place the container in a quiet, cool and shaded location (such as a garage). Make sure the container won't be disturbed. Leave the container for about a week. Do not disturb or move it as much as possible.A week later, you will notice molds growing on the surface. The liquid will have a sweet-sour smell. It may be disturbing but its worth it. It is a sign that beneficial bacteria has inhabited the liquid. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8a\/Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8a\/Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Mix the liquid thoroughly with a stick. Strain the liquid into a large plastic bottle, using a strainer. Leave enough space for the bacteria to breath. The solid materials can be placed into the compost pile, if you have. Otherwise, throw it in the trash. Put the bottle cap loosely on to allow air to enter. Place the bottle in a dark, protected area such as a garage. Application: Mix 1 cup of the liquid to 1 gallon (3.8 L) of chemical-free water. It is best applied early in the morning or late afternoon. Use the diluted liquid to water the plants at their bases. For most plants, apply the diluted FPJ at least once a week.
sentences: Combine the raw materials (see Things You'll Need below) in a 1:1:1 ratio.
Example: 1 kg.
plant materials, 1 kg.
brown sugar, 1 gallon (3.8 L) water.
This can be reduced, just remember the ratio.
Place the materials in a large water-proof container.
Mix the materials together until the sugar is dissolved in water.
Cover the container with a piece of cloth and secure with a rubber band.
Place the container in a quiet, cool and shaded location (such as a garage).
Make sure the container won't be disturbed.
Leave the container for about a week.
Do not disturb or move it as much as possible.A week later, you will notice molds growing on the surface.
The liquid will have a sweet-sour smell.
It may be disturbing but its worth it.
It is a sign that beneficial bacteria has inhabited the liquid.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8a\/Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/8a\/Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Fermented-Plant-Juice-%28Organic-Fertilizer%29-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Mix the liquid thoroughly with a stick.
Strain the liquid into a large plastic bottle, using a strainer.
Leave enough space for the bacteria to breath.
The solid materials can be placed into the compost pile, if you have.
Otherwise, throw it in the trash.
Put the bottle cap loosely on to allow air to enter.
Place the bottle in a dark, protected area such as a garage.
Application: Mix 1 cup of the liquid to 1 gallon (3.8 L) of chemical-free water.
It is best applied early in the morning or late afternoon.
Use the diluted liquid to water the plants at their bases.
For most plants, apply the diluted FPJ at least once a week.
